nodes.text: If an agent seeks to maximize the time-average growth of their wealth then their preferences can be axiomatized and represented by a unique ergodic transformation
Preferences over stochastic wealth processes, satisfying consistency, Archimedean, independence, and monotonicity, admit a linear functional representation on a mixture space

Imposing the Ergodicity Axiom (agents rank processes by long-run time-average growth of a transformed process) pins down the representation so that expected value of the transformation equals its time-average growth

An ergodic transformation f of a stochastic wealth process exists exactly when transforming the process yields stationary independent increments (a Levy process) and thus isolates the time coefficient
Axioms 3.1 (Consistency), 3.2 (Archimedean) and 3.3 (Independence) imply Lemma 3.1 which gives uniqueness properties for mixtures and yields Theorem 3.2 mixture space theorem
Theorem 3.2: Under axioms 3.1 and 3.3 the complete preorder on the mixture space X is representable by a linear functional L : X -> R

Theorem 3.3 (Ergodic vNM): Preferences satisfying axioms 3.1-3.5 are represented by a transformation f such that x >= x' iff E[f(x_t)] >= E[f(x'_t)] and E[f(x_t)] equals the time-average growth limit of f(x_t)
Axiom 3.5 (Ergodicity): x preferred to x' iff the long-run limit of (f(x_t)-f(x0))/t exceeds that of x', which forces f to be the ergodic transformation extracting the growth rate
Using Ito calculus, finding f such that df(x)=alpha dt + beta dW with constants alpha,beta requires the drift a(x) and volatility b(x) satisfy a(x)= (alpha/beta) b(x) + b(x) b'(x)/2
Example: For dx = x^gamma[1 + gamma/2 x^{gamma-1} dt + dW] the ergodic transformation solving f' = 1/b(x) yields f(x) = x^{1-gamma}/(1-gamma)+C, reproducing CRRA-like functional form
Given an ergodic transformation f, maximizing expected f(x_t) is normatively equivalent to maximizing long-run time-average growth

Interpreting f as distinct from classical utility: f need not encode risk attitudes or impatience but when f(x)=x^{1-gamma}/(1-gamma) it numerically matches CRRA forms though gamma is not a behavioral risk aversion parameter here
This axiomatization clarifies when Ergodicity Economics diverges from expected utility models and supplies normative ground to compare EE with multi-period EUT and temporal vNM

Limitations: reliance on infinite time limits (pre-asymptotic life), assumption of known objective dynamics, omission of preferences for early resolution of uncertainty, and potential model misspecification or ambiguity

Suggested extensions: incorporate time-to-convergence preferences for dynamics with equal long-run growth, and extend framework toward ambiguity aversion and robust preferences as in Hansen and Sargent
